text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
I am recreational fisherman and I oppose the listing of the Pacific bluefin tuna as endangered. The result of this ESA listing is important to me.

While the population of Pacific bluefin tuna has, in recent decades, declined to historic levels, the species is not in danger of extinction. The United States Government, NOAA, and the international organizations responsible for management of this pelagic species, the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), took action several years ago to reduce fishing pressure and conserve stocks. The most recent scientific data demonstrates that these international conservation efforts to improve Pacific bluefin tuna stocks have been successful in stabilizing the global population and stocks have already begun the rebuilding process.

Thank you for considering my comments.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: We, NMFS, announce a 90-day finding on a petition to list the Pacific bluefin tuna (Thunnus orientalis) as a threatened or endangered species under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and to designate critical habitat concurrently with the listing.  We find that the petition presents substantial scientific information indicating the petitioned action may be warranted.  We will conduct a status review of the Pacific Bluefin tuna to determine whether the petitioned action is warranted.  To ensure the status review is comprehensive, we are soliciting scientific and commercial information pertaining to this species.

text:
The proposed listing of Thunnus orientalis as an endangered species is untimely, unnecessary, and would be a poor choice in the management of the resource.

It is untimely because it is based, simply put, on the premise that the current population is at roughly 3% of the "original, unfished population." There are two things wrong with this statement: first, it is impossible to exactly count the number of a numerous, pelagic, wide-ranging fish in the vast pacific ocean (even more dubious is the idea that we can know how many there were before we fished for -- or studied -- them); second, the unfished population is a poor metric, as it has no necessary relationship to more relevant metrics like the sustainably fished population, or the minimum species perpetuance baseline. The study that came to this conclusion relies on the estimate* (*emphasis) reached in a study conducted three years ago. Since that time, greater restrictions were put into place and changes in fish behavior have cast doubts on the accuracy of those studies. Off California and New Zealand most notably, large numbers of sexually mature and immature fish have appeared that seem to greatly exceed those old estimates of what was left. Finally, new research has uncovered new spawning areas for the Atlantic bluefin, a markedly similar and even better-studied species, and that they mature at smaller sizes than previously believed. We need to make sure we aren't similarly under-qualifying the Pacific bluefin. Until more research is done to 1) get a more recent population estimate; 2) better define the threshold population at which the species is no longer "threatened" (or what truly constitutes "endangered" -- i.e. at what point the future of the species is truly at risk) 3) confirm the minimum size and age of maturity and 4) determine the major spawning areas, this report is untimely.

While I understand the inclination that it is better to err on the side of caution, I submit that the quantity of fish observed this year in the two aforementioned locales alone -- biomass numbering by all accounts in the millions of tons -- is a sustainable stock that can still provide great value to mankind. This stock can be fished in such a manner that we still extract value from the resource while allowing the stock to simultaneously grow.

The US fishery constitutes about .75-.90 PERCENT of the total catch. We make limited, sustainable use of this fishery. Our listing the species as endangered will be a merely symbolic gesture, and if the fishery were in as grave a state as the proponents of this bill allege, our meek actions here would be in vain.

This listing is therefore unnecessary. There is a sustainable stock of fish that can handle a limited fishing pressure while simultaneously increasing in biomass. The proper means of ensuring that the stock is being utilized responsibly and still growing is working with other jurisdictions to practice and enforce catch quotas, particularly on commercial fisheries. Unless that step is taken, the future of the fish is no better off for our abstinence from fishing them, and it becomes a lose-lose situation.

If this fishery is managed the way it ought to be managed, there are plenty of fish remaining to ensure we will continue to benefit from their existence for generations to come. The recent severe cutbacks in fishing pressure in US waters is a great model of that process in action, and the rapid and marked increase in numbers and size of bluefin tuna observed off the West coast are doubtlessly not a mere coincidence. I encourage the federal agencies charged with this decision to make the right choice for the fish and the persons who enjoy and benefit from the harvest of the resource -- do not list this species as endangered.

Thank you for you time,

Alexander Jassy Selman
label: veryneg
docAbstract: We, NMFS, announce a 90-day finding on a petition to list the Pacific bluefin tuna (Thunnus orientalis) as a threatened or endangered species under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and to designate critical habitat concurrently with the listing.  We find that the petition presents substantial scientific information indicating the petitioned action may be warranted.  We will conduct a status review of the Pacific Bluefin tuna to determine whether the petitioned action is warranted.  To ensure the status review is comprehensive, we are soliciting scientific and commercial information pertaining to this species.

text:
Please do not overreact and list the Pacific Bluefin as endangered. The west coast United States fishery is a highly seasonal but economically significant part of the overall west coast fishery. The United States Bluefin fishery on BOTH coasts is already managed in an appropriate and responsible way with existing regulation.

I also question the accuracy of science based fishery management of any pelagic species. We simply do not know enough about any of the Tunas to list them as endangered because the populations are highly migratory and naturally variant.

Japan and Mexico due far more damage to the stock. Yet despite this, the stock remains healthy and viable. Encouraging the commercial fisheries of those nations to be more responsible and sustainable is a far better approach to the Bluefin stock management.

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.

text: Please lets not try to make flight journey hell with the next seat passanger talking loud over phone. when you are tied to your seat and cant move, the best thing you want to do is sleep. But with allowing passengers talk over phone, lot of passengers will be deprived of this beautiful moment!!
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: NO NO NO NO NO. This would be so incredibly disruptive. There would be people with no respect for others chatting away while people are sleeping right next to them and those sleeping passengers would have no recourse. We do NOT need another source of noise on already noisy aircraft. Please do not allow this.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
Our society's use of electronic devices has become epidemic already. People talk on their cell phones in restaurants, movie theaters, basically anywhere they want. Allowing people to talk on their cell phones while sitting less that two feet away from others who have no means of escape is inviting trouble. Airlines have cut so many corners (way less legroom and smaller seats), as well as paying for baggage, meals, etc., that flying for the average person is an unpleasant experience. If this passes, I hope there is a plan to double or triple the number of sky marshals on board every flight.

This proposal is pure idiocy.

text:
Please do not allow cell-phone calls on any flight. Passengers are overwhelmingly against this change. We are in close quarters with each other, flying is stressful, and being subject to other passengers' loud phone voices will just increase the stress and unpleasantness. Airlines will respond to this rule change by charging passengers more for the opportunity to fly without being disturbed by endless yammering; their support for this change is obviously due to their recognition that it offers one more opportunity to charge customers more.

Have some compassion, please, and don't do this to us.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
This is absolutely the worst idea EVER.
People who use there cell phones in elevators and on public transportation have no sense of their impact on the privacy and sanity of others around them. This would only be amplified on an aircraft where there is no hope for escape.
IF you are seriously considering permitting cell phone use on aircraft, it should be in designated areas only - in the last rows of the plane where disturbing others is least likely - AND a ticketing surcharge should be applied to those seats and credited to those sitting in the 2-3 rows in front of the cell phone permitted zone as conversations in a high ambient noise environment like an airplane will be at top volume as cell phone abusers have no idea how to modulate their voices.
I urge you not to permit voice calls on aircraft.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2015-0827 is yet another example of feel-good overreach WITHOUT any technical method to accomplish these utopian goals without endangering even more human lives.
The mandates which have been imposed in a top-down method have driven up fuel economy by mandating the ever increasing the use of methane producing ethanol which is also detrimental to vehicles not specifically designed for the use of this non-environmentally friendly fuel and the reduction of vehicle weights, which has increased the human injury rates due to the basic physics involved of lighter vehicles provide less occupant protection.
The present Administration, in an open attack on the next generation of Americans, is working to impose its will upon others on the way out the door! The American dream is based on a governmental system which does NOT impose the will of others on us all but was designed, and successful for a couple hundred years, based on free enterprise and personal responsibility.
I must strongly protest these politically driven moves!
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The model year 2017-2025 rule establishing standards for light-duty vehicle greenhouse gases and corporate average fuel economy established a mid-term evaluation process for model year 2022-2025 greenhouse gas standards.  The first step in the mid-term evaluation is a Draft Technical Assessment Report, issued jointly by EPA, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and the California Air Resources Board, to inform EPA’s determination on the appropriateness of the GHG standards and to inform NHTSA’s rulemaking for the CAFE standards for model years 2022-2025.

text: I greatly support the prohibition of Discharges of Vessel Sewage waste in the Puget Sound Waters
label: verypos

text: It is imperative that Puget Sound be declared a No Discharge Zone without further delay. It is far past time that this designation be granted, given not only the adverse economic impact discharges have on the entire ecosystem, but also the degradation of the waters enjoyed by all state residents. Allowing these discharges is yet another example of how the costs of "private pollution" (by tankers, by cruise ships, and by private vessels of all kinds) are socialized, instead of being borne by owners of the vessels. This is wrong. Do the right thing and make the designation immediately.
label: verypos

text: My name is Oliver Patrick and I have worked in the sportfishing industry since 1980.  I currently work for H&M Landing in San DIego, CA.  If you put a ban on the Bluefin Tuna it will totally impact our business in a negative manner.  Our customers come out in the summer time to fish for these Tuna.  The regulations were already changed to a 2 fish bag limit per person, I totally supported that change.  This past summer there were giant schools of Bluefin every day.  How you can say they are an endangered species is ridiculous.  Maybe you should come out some time and see for yourself.  We did not have a big Yellowfin season this year with the cooler water so our fleet relied heavily on the Bluefin Tuna.  The small amount of Bluefin that the fleet caught in no way would impact the entire species.  Please do not restrict the Bluefin Tuna any more than you already have.  Why fix something that is not broken.
label: veryneg

text:
Navy Region Northwest Comment on the Petition for Determination That Adequate Facilities for the Safe
and Sanitary Removal and Treatment of Sewage From All Vessels Are Reasonably Available for the
Waters of Puget Sound

Navy Region Northwest appreciates the opportunity to comment on EPA's tentative
determination that adequate facilities for the safe and sanitary removal and treatment
of sewage from all vessels are reasonably available for waters subject to Washington's
planned No Discharge Zone.

Navy Region Northwest recognizes that the compilation of facilities included recognition
of three stationary facilities dedicated to Navy vessel usage.

Although EPA does not specifically ask for comment or clarifications related to the
petition for a No Discharge Zone, we would like to mention the following comment for EPA
and WA Department of Ecology consideration as you finalize the determination.

Comment: Navy Region Northwest recommends that military vessels be defined in
accordance with the definition provided at Clean Water Act Section 312 (a)(14) and recognized
as a class of vessels distinct from commercial vessels while considering the proposed
establishment of a No Discharge Zone (NDZ) for Washington State's Puget Sound waters.
The petition currently does not distinguish or define vessels of the Armed Forces.

Clean Water Act Section 312 (a)(14) defines "vessel of the Armed Forces" as follows:

(14) "vessel of the Armed Forces" means --
(A) any vessel owned or operated by the Department of Defense, other than a time or voyage chartered vessel; and
(B) any vessel owned or operated by the Department of Transportation that is designated by the Secretary of the
department in which the Coast Guard is operating as a vessel equivalent to a vessel described in subparagraph (A).

Navy Region Northwest recommends the No Discharge Zone determination make explicit that its application to
vessels of the Armed Forces is subject to the authority of Clean Water Act Section 312 (d).

Rationale: Clarifying the definition of "vessel of the Armed Forces" will recognize the authority granted by Congress
to the Secretary of Defense to determine when compliance with standards and regulations under Clean Water Act
Section 312 would not be in the interest of national security. Pursuant to Section 312 (d), the Secretary of Defense
promulgated DoD 4715.06-R1 Regulations on Vessels Owned or Operated by the Department of Defense
(January 2005). This Regulation exempts, at certain times and under certain circumstances, some vessels from the
sewage discharge requirements of the Clean Water Act when compliance for certain vessels "would excessively and
unreasonably detract from their military characteristics, effectiveness, or safety to not be in the interest of national security."
The regulation nonetheless requires vessels of the Armed Forces to limit discharge of sewage into U.S. navigable
waters, territorial seas, and EPA delineated "No Discharge Zones" designated under the Clean Water Act to the
maximum extent practicable without endangering the health, safety, or welfare of the crew or other personnel aboard.
Therefore, Commanding Officers limit discharges to the maximum extent practicable and use pump out facilities before
departure from port or attempt to limit discharges to allowed areas out to sea; but, there may be occasional need for
some vessels to discharge within the No Discharge Zone.
label: neg

text:
To the EPA:
I support a No Discharge Zone for Puget Sound and Lake Washington. As our region
works to recover the health of our ecosystem and keep our waters clean for humans and
wildlife, this is an important step.
This has been a long time coming! We need to address all sources of pollution to Puget
Sound so that we can restore its health.
Puget Sound has sufficient vessel sewage pump-out facilities and capacity to support the
Puget Sound No Discharge Zone. Please affirm the No Discharge Zone.
Sincerely,
Janet Seki
144 NE 62nd St
Seattle, WA 98115
label: verypos

text:
Dear Sirs,
I've added some basic information from our boaters association below. I also want you to know that what little sewage the recreational boats add is but a drop in the bucket compared to the city's bordering the sound are putting into Puget Sound every day. Do your due diligence before you pass another knee jerk reaction law.
Dan Rivera
PO Box 1502
Gig Harbor, WA 98335

The Department of Ecology's plan to designate all of Puget Sound a No Discharge Zone is regulatory overkill, is not based on sound science, and should not go forward;

Independent water quality scientists have found that models used by Ecology dramatically overstated the volume and composition of vessel discharges into the Puget Sound;

We believe in Clean Water, and we could even support scientifically-based, targeted No Discharge Zones in shellfish and low-flushing areas;

Remember: Raw sewage discharges are already illegal within three miles of the shoreline, and many boaters treat sewage discharges now with Coast Guard-approved type I and type II Marine Sanitation Devices (MSDs), which will be outlawed by the proposed NDZ.

Please say NO to regulatory overkill - let's ask Ecology to focus on the real problems causing water quality impairment.The biggest ones involve the billions of gallons of raw sewage dumped by Victoria, B.C. as well as (during storm events) by King County METRO and Seattle Public Utilities.B
label: neg

text: While I believe in restricting the harvest of Pacific Bluefin Tuna, it is the commercial industry that should have new regulations imposed. Sport fishing is the most sustainable way to take a bluefin, other than by harpoon. Seiners and long-liners, especially those south of the border are the ones that have a significant impact if anyone does. Why attack an industry that has little to no effect on the species, when in plain sight, the commercial industry is where the problem truly lies. Or course, big business and politics are too tightly tied to the problem to see this rationale.
label: veryneg

text:
I have fished recreationally in the waters ranging from Costa Rica to Northern California. I can tell you from personal experience that bluefin are a very hard fish to catch hook and line fishing. They require one to use undersized tackle to just get a bite which most often results in not getting the fish to the boat. This past season I spent nearly 200 hours and a few thousand dollars fishing these fish, spotting thousands of bluefin crashing on the surface and even more underneath the surface on my depth sounder each and everyday I fished. In those 200 hours of pain staking and frustrating fishing I was only able to hook 6 fish and actually bring 4 in to the boat. As was the results for many of my friends who recreationally fish. I can personally vouch that recreational fishing does not and could never pose a real threat to the populations of these fish, especially considering that the daily limit is already only 2 fish per day. These fish come in to our local waters for a brief window of time each year. So we as recreational fishermen are only able to get the opportunity for a short amount of time and considering the difficulty of getting one to bite a hooked bait and then winning the battle to the boat, I would say the odds are on the fishes side.

So with all that said, to put a ban on all bluefin fishing would be a very heart felt blow to the few hundred people I personally know of in my fishing community. Not to mention a very significant reduction of revenue to our community and nation.

The focus of the regulation should be pointed at the big corporations who use unfair means to catch these fish, such as seiners. Banning all fishing of these fish would eventually result in an over abundance of the species, which in turn would have adverse effects on the prey of the species. Humans play a role in the population balance of the environment and cannot be completely removed. If seiners were replaced with jig stick boats where the fish has to bite a bait, the schools would not be completely removed and continue to be able to reproduce among the remaining fish.

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
I am recreational fisherman and I oppose the listing of the Pacific bluefin tuna as endangered. The result of this ESA listing is important to me.

While the population of Pacific bluefin tuna has, in recent decades, declined to historic levels, the species is not in danger of extinction. The United States Government, NOAA, and the international organizations responsible for management of this pelagic species, the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), took action several years ago to reduce fishing pressure and conserve stocks. The most recent scientific data demonstrates that these international conservation efforts to improve Pacific bluefin tuna stocks have been successful in stabilizing the global population and stocks have already begun the rebuilding process.

Thank you for considering my comments.

text:
I am recreational fisherman and I oppose the listing of the Pacific bluefin tuna as endangered. The result of this ESA listing is important to me.

While the population of Pacific bluefin tuna has, in recent decades, declined to historic levels, the species is not in danger of extinction. The United States Government, NOAA, and the international organizations responsible for management of this pelagic species, the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), took action several years ago to reduce fishing pressure and conserve stocks. The most recent scientific data demonstrates that these international conservation efforts to improve Pacific bluefin tuna stocks have been successful in stabilizing the global population and stocks have already begun the rebuilding process.

Thank you for considering my comments.

text:
Hello,

I am a Certified Medical Examiner (CME) under the FMCSA program to provide physicals for commercial motor vehicle operators. I have performed well over a thousand physicals for this program in the past 8 years. I am a Doctor of Chiropractic (DC).

It is my understanding that this current proposal excludes DCs in the VA from being included in the program to certify doctors to perform physicals on driver in the VA system. This is troubling for a few reasons. 1) DCs such as myself are able to become CMEs under the FMCSA rules. This should be no different for DCs within the VA system. 2) DCs are indeed included within the VA system and are on staff at numerous VA facilities across the nation. 3) The skills and knowledge required for the CDL exams are well within our training. Every part of the CDL exam is covered on the National Board exams that all DCs take as a condition to be eligible for a license. 4) The VA system is struggling to keep up with demand, and it make no sense to exclude a class of providers perfectly capable of providing this service.

As noted above, there are several reasons to include DCs within this program. The only reason to exclude is due to inter-professional politics AKA "turf war". Do what is right for our veteran drivers. Include DCs in this program.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Process for Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Physicians to be Added to the National Registry of Certified Medical Examiners

text:
The recreational fisherman is not the problem:

Pacific bluefin are a very LOW RETENTION species. I have fished many times this year (and years past for that matter) and seen thousands of fish, yet the boat catches single digits of them for the whole trip? Our impact on these schools is minimal (when they are even around to catch). We also reduced our limit last year from 5 to 2, so its even smaller now.
According to CBDs own petition, US recreational fishermen have only caught 12-809 metric tons of bluefin per year since 1990, which is less than a tenth of the total catch across the Pacific (8,000-34,000 mt annually) those same years. The vast majority of bluefin are caught by commercial purse seine and longline gears. We already gave! Further regulation of the U.S. recreational fishery would have UNDUE ECONOMIC IMPACT, with little to no benefit to the bluefin population.

Thank You,
Brian Knott
31562 Catalina Ave
Laguna Beach, CA
92651

949-422-2090

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
I am recreational fisherman and I oppose the listing of the Pacific bluefin tuna as endangered. The result of this ESA listing is important to me.

While the population of Pacific bluefin tuna has, in recent decades, declined to historic levels, the species is not in danger of extinction. The United States Government, NOAA, and the international organizations responsible for management of this pelagic species, the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), took action several years ago to reduce fishing pressure and conserve stocks. The most recent scientific data demonstrates that these international conservation efforts to improve Pacific bluefin tuna stocks have been successful in stabilizing the global population and stocks have already begun the rebuilding process.

Thank you for considering my comments.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: We, NMFS, announce a 90-day finding on a petition to list the Pacific bluefin tuna (Thunnus orientalis) as a threatened or endangered species under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) and to designate critical habitat concurrently with the listing.  We find that the petition presents substantial scientific information indicating the petitioned action may be warranted.  We will conduct a status review of the Pacific Bluefin tuna to determine whether the petitioned action is warranted.  To ensure the status review is comprehensive, we are soliciting scientific and commercial information pertaining to this species.

text:
My name is Michael Moore, a recently retired Firefighter who has been EXTREMELY ACTIVE fishing Southern California waters since 1968. I have worked as a licensed 100-ton Master issued by the U.S. Coast Guard operating vessels in California for decades. I know own and operate a 25-foot sportfisher here in Southern California.

Spending the past 40-years pursueing the highly ELUSIVE Bluefin tuna reveals how incredibly difficult it is to hook even a single bluefin over the course of an entire season as these fish almost always refuse to take baited hooks using live bait on the lightest of gear. Typical years the average size of bluefin here range 10-30 lbs. Medium size fish in the 40-60 lb range are less common. Larger 60-80 lb fish showing in our waters is an EXTREMELY RARE EVENT. Regardless of the bluefins size, hooking a bluefin of any size is in a typical year is indeed is a very rare event and the few bluefin actually caught remains extremely low so closing this fishery serves no reasonable purpose to help rebuild the stock of this tuna species.

I wish to close by saying that closing down the bluefin fishery here in California makes ZERO sense as these fish are rarely if ever hooked and the ones that are landed are almost never of breeder size. Taking such an extreme measure to close the entire bluefin fishery is nothing less than an ill advised since it"s based on bad science. Furthermore, closing the bluefin fishery will result in extreme hardship to the all sportfishing communities, it's industry, related operations, bait companies, tackle companies, tackle stores, sport fishing vessels, commercial fisherman, and the heavy loss of tax revenues to the suffering economy in California. This is nothing short of a POOR idea so please put a stop to this movement immediately.

Respectfully, Michael Moore

label: neut
docAbstract:
Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.
